msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B. K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No. 2628 Return to Petiton and Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable Edward E. Cushman, Judge of the Above Entitled Court:
Comes now Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, and for answer to the Writ of Habeas Corpus issued herein, and for answer to the petition filed herein, states as follows:
I. That he has not knowledge and information sufficient to form a belief as to the matters set forth in Paragraph I of the said petition, and therefore denies the same.

II. That he admits that the warrant for arrest is in terms and figures as set forth on page two and that the warrant for deportation is as set forth on page three of the petition, and that the petitioners were arrested and held under said two warrants; but he denies each and every other allegation set forth in said Paragraph II.
III. That he admits the allegations set forth in Paragraph III. ending at the words "from the United States to Japan" in line twenty-eight of page three of said petition.

That he admits allegations of Paragraph III commencing at line thirty of page three and ending at the end of the paragraph; but that he denies all of the other allegations in Paragraph III save and except what is herein especially admitted.

IV. That he admits the allegation set forth in Paragraph IV, ending at line twenty-six of page four, except that the petitioners had a "pretended" hearing, and alleges as a matter of fact that the petitioners' hearing on the 17th day of October, 1913, was a fair and regular hearing.
That he has not knowledge and information sufficient to form a belief as to whether notice and opportunity were given to the petitioners and their attorneys to appear, and therefore denies the same.

He admits that the petitioners did not cross-examine the affiants; admits that the petitioners were not confronted by affiants, and that affiants at no time appeared before petitioners; admits that the attorney for petitioner appeared at the time of the taking of the affidavit of Shotaro Washio, and that the petitioners did not appear at that time; and denies each and every other allegation set forth in Paragraph IV, save and except what is especially admitted.

V. As to allegation set forth in Paragraph V, he admits that portion of the same ending at "United States" in line twenty on page give, and denies each and every other allegation set forth in Paragraph V.

VI. As to the allegation set forth in Paragraph VI, he admits that portion of the same ending at the words "being detained at said station" in line twenty of page seven, and denies each and every other allegation thereof.
VII. That he denies each and every allegation of the petition for "a Writ of Habeas Corpus, save and except what is herein especially admitted.
And for a further and separate answer and return to said application for a writ of Habeas Corpus, and for Further Return to said Writ said Henry M. White alleges as follows:

I. That on October 17, 1913, a hearing was had before B.A. Hunter, the Inspector and Examiner, at which hearing the said petitioners appeared in person and by their attorney, Robert W. McClelland, and that the testimony and all the proceedings were transcribed by the stenographer, Walter P. Harris, and said transcript is marked "Exhibit A" and made a part of this return; that at such hearing the petitioners were given opportunity to put in all their testimony and there was no objection whatever raised to the exhibits 3
that were put in evidence by the Government, and that the petitioners were especially questioned as to the sworn affidavits or statements put in by the Government.

II. That is is impossible for the Department of Labor to make an investigation concerning the charges set forth in said warrant without the knowledge of this office, and that it never makes an investigation independent of the local Immigration Officee, and that no hearing or investigation was made other than that set forth in "Exhibit A".

III. That there are sufficient facts shown in the record to justify a finding that the petitioners should be deported, and that the Court has no authority to determine anything in a habeas corpus proceeding, except whether or not the petitioners were deprived of a fair hearing, or whether as a matter of law from the facts the petitioners should be deported.

IV. That the testimony of Shotaro Washio shows that petitioners should be deported on the warrant, and that the only way the Court could grant a writ would be in reversing the Department in its ruling on the facts; that the petitioners are, therefore, being legally held on the warrant set forth in Paragraph II of the petition and should be deported as therein ordered.

Wherefore said Henry M. White prays the 4
above entitled court that the said writ be dismissed and the application and petition denied.
United States of America, Western District of Washington. } ss.

Henry M. White, being first duly sowrn, upon his oath deposes and says: That he is the party named in the foregoing answer; that he has read the same, knows the contents thereof and verily believes the same to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 7th day of January, A. D. 1914.
